articles.title: How Small Is Too Small? Volunteers Help NASA Test Lake Monitoring From Space
articles.summary: Volunteers participating in the Lake Observations by Citizen Scientists and Satellites (LOCSS) project have been collecting water level data in lakes since 2017. Now, the LOCSS team has used these data to examine the accuracy of water level measurements made from space.
articles.content:
Jen Oden, Snohomish County Water Quality Specialist, and Megan Lane, LOCSS team member, report a lake height measurement at Flowing Lake, Snohomish County, Washington. Visit locss.org to contact the team or to get involved! Grant Parkins, 2018

Volunteers participating in the Lake Observations by Citizen Scientists and Satellites (LOCSS) project have been collecting water level data in lakes since 2017. Now, the LOCSS team has used these data to examine the accuracy of water level measurements made from space. The results, published in GIScience & Remote Sensing, showed that modern satellites with special instruments called nadir altimeters can capture water level variation with relatively high accuracy even for lakes smaller than one square kilometer. These measurements are crucial for scientific research and resource management.

“We can look at the wetland now with different eyes,” said Nelsi Durán, a volunteer from Ciénaga La Musanda, Colombia. (Translated from Spanish).

The work done by LOCSS volunteers also helped reveal where satellite-based lake water level measurements can go wrong. Water level variability turns out to be an important factor. Relatively small lakes with a high lake level variability can be measured from space, but lakes where the water level seldom changes yielded measurements with lower accuracy.

The LOCSS project has included 274 lakes in 10 countries (USA, Canada, Colombia, Chile, Kenya, Spain, France, India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh), so far. Since the project started, more than 10,000 citizen scientists have reported water level measurements to the project.

“We chose to work with the LOCSS team, because it is important for us to try to widen our understanding of how our environments change over time,” said Dan Grigas, an ecologist at Forest Preserve District, DuPage County, Illinois. “This includes how changes in climate patterns in both the near-term and long-term can affect freshwater ecology. This program also allows for and relies on citizen scientists to participate, which strengthens the relationships among government agencies, the people they serve, and the environments that we all treasure.”

Are you passionate about understanding our planet and its precious water resources? Visit locss.org and look for a participating lake near you!
articles.reasoning: The article describes a citizen science project with broad international participation that improves the accuracy of satellite-based lake water level monitoring, which is crucial for environmental research and resource management. It highlights meaningful collaboration between volunteers and scientists, contributing to better understanding of freshwater ecology and climate change impacts.
articles.personality_title: Volunteers Help NASA Test Satellite Monitoring of Small Lakes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Since 2017, a project called Lake Observations by Citizen Scientists and Satellites (LOCSS) has invited volunteers around the world to measure water levels in lakes. This helps scientists check how well satellites can track lake water levels from space.

**What happened** – LOCSS volunteers collected water level data from 274 lakes in 10 countries, including the USA, Colombia, and India. Using these volunteer reports, the LOCSS team studied how accurate satellite instruments called nadir altimeters are when measuring lake heights. They found satellites can measure changes in small lakes, even those less than one square kilometer in size, quite well, especially when lake water levels change often.

**Impact** – This work shows satellites can monitor small lakes better than previously thought. It also reveals that lakes with little change in water level are harder to measure accurately from space. These findings help scientists improve how they track freshwater resources and understand environmental changes, like those caused by climate shifts.

**What's next step** – The LOCSS project encourages more people to join and submit lake data. With more volunteer measurements, scientists can keep improving satellite monitoring and better protect freshwater ecosystems around the world.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Volunteer-collected lake data are helping NASA improve satellite monitoring of small lakes, supporting better environmental research and water resource management worldwide.

articles.personality_title_es: Voluntarios ayudan a la NASA a probar el monitoreo satelital de lagos pequeños
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde 2017, un proyecto llamado Lake Observations by Citizen Scientists and Satellites (LOCSS) invita a voluntarios de todo el mundo a medir los niveles de agua en lagos. articles.title: How to Recycle Makeup
articles.summary:
Makeup is making the planet ugly. The beauty industry generates approximately 120 billion packaging items...
The post How to Recycle Makeup appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Makeup is making the planet ugly. The beauty industry generates approximately 120 billion packaging items annually, most of which end up in landfills. Most beauty packaging is too small, made of mixed materials, or too flexible to be accepted by municipal curbside recycling programs. Compacts, lipstick tubes, mascara wands, pumps, and travel-size containers are typically not accepted at standard recycling facilities.

A growing number of brands, retailers, and nonprofit organizations have responded by creating specialized recycling programs for hard-to-recycle beauty packaging. This shift reflects increasing corporate awareness of the industry’s environmental impact—and presents an opportunity for consumers to support companies that take responsibility for their products throughout their life cycles.

Before diving into recycling options, consider purging your makeup collection first. Empty out every bag, drawer, suitcase, and purse: no compact left behind. First, determine what’s no longer needed. Check expiration dates and color-match everything. A clean and safe makeup collection requires staying up to date on everything in it.

Get Ready To Recycle Makeup

Start with that old makeup at the back of the drawer or the bottom of the bag. Maybe it came as a freebie, maybe it’s been years since that bronzer saw the light of day, or maybe a color just never worked. Whatever the case, most people have items they’ve kept around for some reason.

If products are gently used or unopened and still within their shelf life, look up local women’s shelters. Many accept cosmetics donations, sanitize them, and distribute them to women who otherwise couldn’t afford them. Organizations like Project Glimmer also distribute beauty products to underserved women and girls.

For products that are definitely used or empty, check whether the brand has a recycling program. If no buy-back option exists, consider reusing the container—clean it thoroughly and repurpose it for storage, DIY projects, or offer it to someone who makes their own cosmetics.

Once reuse options are exhausted, recycling programs can ensure packaging doesn’t end up in a landfill. The options available have expanded significantly, with Pact Collective now offering drop-off locations and multiple brands operating take-back programs.

Preparing Empties for Drop-Off

All packaging must be clean and empty. Contaminated items, that is, packaging with product residue, cannot be recycled and will be sent to waste-to-energy instead. By cleaning empties thoroughly, consumers increase the likelihood that packaging will be mechanically recycled into new products.

Save at least 5 empties before cleaning to reduce water usage.

Disassemble caps, pumps, and closures to clean each component

Soak items in hot, soapy water rather than running them under hot water continuously.

Use straw brushes for small openings, such as mascara tubes.

Cut open flexible tubes to thoroughly clean the inside.

Drop items into bins unbagged.

Check Local Recycling Options

Municipal recycling rules and what is accepted still vary significantly by location. Before assuming packaging must go to a specialized program, check what your local program accepts. Some cities now accept all plastics regardless of resin code, while others remain limited to #1 and #2 containers. Use Earth911’s Recycling Search to find recycling options near you, including both curbside programs and specialized drop-off locations.

Send these items through your curbside recycling bin:

Rigid plastic containers #1, #2, and #5

Stainless steel or aluminum containers

Clear or frosted glass jars and bottles (check local guidelines)

Hazardous materials that require special disposal (check Earth911 for household hazardous waste locations):

Aerosol products

Nail polish and nail polish remover

Pressurized containers

Pact Collective: Industry-Wide Beauty Recycling

Pact Collective is a nonprofit organization founded in 2021 by MOB Beauty and Credo Beauty to collect beauty packaging waste across the industry. Now with over 150 member companies, including L’Oréal, Sephora, Ulta Beauty, ILIA, and Summer Fridays, Pact represents a significant shift toward collective corporate responsibility.

Pact is brand-agnostic: any beauty packaging that meets Pact’s collection guidelines can be dropped off, regardless of whether the brand is a Pact member. This approach prioritizes volume collection over brand loyalty, making participation straightforward for consumers.

Pact Drop-Off Locations

Pact maintains over 3,300 collection bin locations across North America at major beauty retailers:

Ulta Beauty : All 1,350+ U.S. locations through The Beauty Dropoff program, the largest beauty packaging collection program by door count in the country

: All 1,350+ U.S. locations through The Beauty Dropoff program, the largest beauty packaging collection program by door count in the country Sephora : All 600+ North American stores through the Beauty (Re)Purposed program

: All 600+ North American stores through the Beauty (Re)Purposed program Credo Beauty : All locations (Credo is a Pact co-founder and contributes roughly 50% of material collected from in-store bins despite representing only 1% of Pact’s bin footprint)

: All locations (Credo is a Pact co-founder and contributes roughly 50% of material collected from in-store bins despite representing only 1% of Pact’s bin footprint) L’Occitane en Provence : Participating stores

: Participating stores Saks Fifth Avenue : Participating stores

: Participating stores Nordstrom Rack : Participating stores

: Participating stores ILIA and Fenty Beauty: Select locations

What Pact Accepts

Hard-to-recycle beauty packaging smaller than a fist:

Mascara tubes and wands

Lipstick tubes and lip gloss containers

Compact cases and palettes

Eyeliner pencils and containers

Foundation bottles and tubes

Small skincare containers

Pumps, caps, and closures

Flexible tubes (squeezable packaging)

Pact Mail-Back Program

Consumers without access to a drop-off bin can use the Pact paid mail-back program. The service costs $5 for a prepaid shipping label, and some partner brands offer discount codes to help offset the cost. Pact encourages using in-store bins when possible, as bulk shipping is more environmentally efficient than individual mail-back packages.

Brand Take-Back Programs

Several beauty brands operate their own recycling programs, reflecting growing recognition that companies bear responsibility for their packaging through the end of life. Supporting brands with take-back programs sends a market signal that sustainability matters to consumers.

MAC Cosmetics: Back 2 MAC

One of the longest-running beauty recycling programs, Back 2 MAC has operated for over 30 years. Return clean, empty MAC packaging in-store or online for recycling through a partnership with Close the Loop. MAC’s signature black plastic is processed through a closed-loop system and remanufactured into new MAC compacts. Items not eligible include liquid lipsticks, glitters, pigments, fragrances, nail lacquers, and aerosols. The program is not available in California due to local regulations.

Lush: Bring It Back

Lush operates a closed-loop recycling system for their iconic black polypropylene pots. Return clean #5 PP plastic pots (4.5g/1.5oz and larger), including makeup packaging like mascara tubes and lip tubes, to any Lush store. In exchange, receive $1 off per item returned, or bring five items for a free fresh face mask. The returned plastic is shredded, washed, pelletized, and remolded into new Lush pots. In 2024, Lush’s Green Hub processed over 1,700 tons of waste, with an 18% return rate on pots produced—up from 15% the previous year.

TerraCycle Programs

TerraCycle partners with brands and retailers to offer beauty packaging recycling through both free brand-sponsored programs and paid Zero Waste Boxes. Free programs are available through brands including Burt’s Bees, Farmacy, Bliss, and LimeLife by Alcone. Retailers like Nordstrom’s BEAUTYCYCLE program and Saks Fifth Avenue partner with TerraCycle to collect and process makeup packaging through in-store and mail-in programs.

According to TerraCycle’s life-cycle analysis, their beauty waste recycling process is 74% better for the environment than landfills and 67% better than waste-to-energy, with 98% of collected waste recycled.

Buying Responsibly

The biggest lesson in makeup disposal is how products get there in the first place. The most important step you can take to reduce beauty packaging waste happens when you make a purchase. Choose brands that take responsibility for their environmental impact:

Choose refillable packaging: Many brands now offer refill options for foundations, lipsticks, and compacts. Purchasing refills instead of entirely new packaging significantly reduces waste.

Look for packaging-free products: Solid shampoo bars, bar cleansers, and other “naked” products eliminate packaging entirely. Lush pioneered this approach, with 30-50% of their products sold without packaging, and many other brands now offer solid alternatives.

Support Pact Collective members: Brands that are Pact members have committed to improving packaging sustainability and funding collection programs. The organization’s 150+ members include L’Oréal, Credo Beauty, Summer Fridays, ILIA, Fenty Beauty, and many indie brands.

Consider mono-material packaging: Products packaged in a single material type (like all-polypropylene containers) are easier to recycle than mixed-material packaging with metal springs, multiple plastic types, or glass-and-plastic combinations.

Use what you have: Before buying new products, use the ones you already have completely. Check expiration dates on current makeup and finish products before replacing them.

Makeup recycling options have expanded considerably. With Pact Collective’s 3,300+ bin locations at major retailers and its multiple brand take-back programs, there are more pathways to keep cosmetics packaging out of landfills. Remember the key steps:

Clean empties thoroughly, check what’s accepted by the recycling program, and drop off or mail back.

For curbside-recyclable items (larger containers in #1, #2, or #5 plastic), use your municipal recycling program.

For hard-to-recycle items smaller than a fist, Pact offers the most accessible solution.

The growing range of recycling options reflects the beauty industry’s increasing awareness of its environmental impact. Supporting brands and retailers that invest in take-back programs, collection infrastructure, and circular packaging design helps accelerate this shift, making it easier for everyone to be a friend of the planet, and that’s beautiful.

Editor’s Note: This article was originally published on January 2, 2017, and we most recently updated in December 2025. Feature mage courtesy of Shutterstock.com
articles.reasoning: The article highlights significant progress in addressing environmental pollution caused by makeup packaging through expanded recycling programs, corporate responsibility initiatives, and consumer guidance. It details broad, impactful actions involving major brands and nonprofits, providing substantial context on how these efforts reduce landfill waste and promote sustainability in the beauty industry.
articles.personality_title: New recycling programs help reduce makeup waste and protect the planet
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, the beauty industry produces about 120 billion pieces of packaging, like lipstick tubes and compact cases. Most of these items are too small or made of mixed materials, so they usually can’t be recycled through regular city programs and often end up in landfills.

**What happened** – To fix this problem, many beauty brands, stores, and nonprofits have started special recycling programs for makeup packaging. For example, Pact Collective, a group with over 150 member companies including big names like L’Oréal and Sephora, offers more than 3,300 drop-off bins across North America where people can bring empty makeup containers. Other brands like MAC and Lush also run their own recycling programs where customers can return empty packaging for proper recycling.

**Impact** – These new programs make it easier to recycle makeup packaging that usually can’t be recycled at home. This helps keep plastic, metal, and glass waste out of landfills. It also encourages companies to be responsible for their products even after customers finish using them. For example, Lush recycles returned pots into new containers, and MAC turns old packaging into new makeup cases.

**What’s next step** – People can start by cleaning out old makeup, checking expiration dates, and donating unused products to local women’s shelters. Then they can use these special recycling bins or mail-back programs to recycle empty containers. Buying makeup with refillable or packaging-free options can also reduce waste in the future. As more brands join these programs, recycling will become even easier and more common.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New recycling programs from beauty brands and retailers are making it easier to recycle makeup packaging and reduce waste that harms the environment.

**Contexte** – Chaque année, l’industrie de la beauté produit environ 120 milliards d’emballages, comme les tubes de rouge à lèvres et les boîtiers compacts. articles.personality_title_es: Nuevos programas de reciclaje ayudan a reducir los desechos de maquillaje y protegen el planeta
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, la industria de la belleza produce alrededor de 120 mil millones de empaques, como tubos de lápiz labial y estuches compactos. La mayoría de estos artículos son demasiado pequeños o están hechos con materiales mezclados, por lo que normalmente no pueden reciclarse en los programas municipales y terminan en vertederos.

También anima a las empresas a responsabilizarse de sus productos después de que los clientes los usan. Por ejemplo, Lush recicla sus envases para hacer otros nuevos, y MAC convierte los empaques usados en nuevos estuches.

**Próximo paso** – Las personas pueden empezar limpiando su maquillaje viejo, revisando fechas de vencimiento y donando productos no usados a refugios de mujeres. articles.title: Press release - Parliament endorses simpler rules and more support for farmers
articles.summary: MEPs adopted new rules on Tuesday introducing more flexibility and support for farmers in complying with the EU’s common agricultural policy (CAP).Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
The preliminary agreement, reached by Parliament and Council negotiators on 10 November 2025, was adopted by 629 votes to 17 and with 16 abstentions.

Support to small farmers

The co-legislators agreed that small farms can be supported with up to €3,000 of annual financial support, instead of an initial €2,500 proposed by the Commission and an additional new one-off business development payment of up to €75,000, rising from the previously proposed €50,000.

Environmental requirements

To help preserve biodiversity and spare farmers the expensive and labour-intensive task of ploughing their fields, the new rules ensure land classified as arable as of 1 January 2026 will retain this designation, even if it has not been ploughed, tilled, or reseeded.

Farmers certified as organic will automatically be considered as having met the Good Agricultural and Environmental Condition (GAEC) standards requirements for the parts of their farms that are either already organic or in the process of being converted to organic farming. Member States will be allowed to limit this simplification in case controls would create high administrative burden.

Fewer on-the-spot checks

Inspections will take place according to the so-called “once only” principle, so farmers will not have to undergo more than one official check on-the-spot in any given year.

Quote

Rapporteur André Rodrigues (S&D, PT) said: "Farmers need clear rules, less bureaucracy and payments they can rely on. What we approved today proves what we have defended since the beginning: we can have simpler rules and better support, without weakening environmental and social protections."

Next steps:

The provisional agreement now needs to be formally approved by the Council. It will enter into force a day after being published in the EU Official Journal.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the EU Parliament adopting new agricultural policy rules that simplify compliance for farmers, increase financial support especially for small farms, and include environmental protections such as preserving biodiversity and supporting organic farming. This has broad positive impact on farmers across the EU and promotes sustainable agriculture with clear environmental benefits.
articles.personality_title: EU Parliament approves simpler rules and more support for farmers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union has a common agricultural policy (CAP) that sets rules and support for farmers across member countries. These rules help guide farming practices and provide financial aid.

**What happened** – On 10 November 2025, the EU Parliament voted overwhelmingly to approve new rules for farmers. These changes make it easier for farmers to follow the CAP, increase financial support for small farms from €2,500 to €3,000 per year, and add a one-time payment of up to €75,000 to help develop farming businesses. The new rules also protect land classified as arable even if it isn’t ploughed every year and simplify environmental checks for organic farmers. Inspections will be reduced so farmers only face one on-the-spot check per year.

**Impact** – These updates help farmers by reducing paperwork and giving them more money, especially benefiting smaller farms. At the same time, the rules support the environment by protecting farmland biodiversity and encouraging organic farming. This balance helps farmers maintain their livelihoods while caring for the land.

**What's next step** – The Council of the European Union still needs to formally approve the new rules. Once approved and published in the EU Official Journal, the rules will come into effect the following day.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU has approved clearer, simpler farming rules that increase support for farmers and protect the environment at the same time.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen adopte des règles simplifiées et plus de soutien pour les agriculteurs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne a une politique agricole commune (PAC) qui fixe des règles et un soutien pour les agriculteurs des pays membres. Ces règles aident à guider les pratiques agricoles et à fournir une aide financière.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 10 novembre 2025, le Parlement européen a voté massivement pour approuver de nouvelles règles pour les agriculteurs. Ces changements facilitent le respect de la PAC, augmentent le soutien financier aux petites exploitations de 2 500 € à 3 000 € par an, et ajoutent un paiement unique pouvant aller jusqu'à 75 000 € pour aider au développement des entreprises agricoles. Les nouvelles règles protègent aussi les terres classées arables même si elles ne sont pas labourées chaque année et simplifient les contrôles environnementaux pour les agriculteurs bio. Les inspections seront réduites à une seule visite annuelle.

**Impact** – Ces mises à jour aident les agriculteurs en réduisant la paperasse et en leur donnant plus d'argent, surtout pour les petites exploitations. En même temps, les règles soutiennent l'environnement en protégeant la biodiversité des terres agricoles et en encourageant l'agriculture biologique. Cet équilibre aide les agriculteurs à vivre de leur travail tout en prenant soin de la terre.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Conseil de l'Union européenne doit encore approuver formellement ces nouvelles règles. Une fois approuvées et publiées au Journal officiel de l'UE, elles entreront en vigueur le lendemain.

**Phrase clé** – L'UE a adopté des règles agricoles plus claires et simples qui augmentent le soutien aux agriculteurs tout en protégeant l'environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento de la UE aprueba reglas más simples y mayor apoyo a los agricultores
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea tiene una política agrícola común (PAC) que establece reglas y apoyos para los agricultores de los países miembros. Estas reglas ayudan a guiar las prácticas agrícolas y a proporcionar ayuda financiera.

**Qué pasó** – El 10 de noviembre de 2025, el Parlamento Europeo aprobó con gran mayoría nuevas reglas para los agricultores. Estos cambios facilitan que los agricultores cumplan con la PAC, aumentan el apoyo financiero a las pequeñas granjas de 2.500 € a 3.000 € al año, y añaden un pago único de hasta 75.000 € para ayudar a desarrollar negocios agrícolas. Las nuevas reglas también protegen las tierras clasificadas como arables aunque no se labren cada año y simplifican las inspecciones ambientales para los agricultores orgánicos. Las inspecciones se reducirán a una sola visita anual.

**Impacto** – Estas actualizaciones ayudan a los agricultores al reducir el papeleo y darles más dinero, especialmente a las pequeñas granjas. Al mismo tiempo, las reglas apoyan el medio ambiente al proteger la biodiversidad de las tierras agrícolas y fomentar la agricultura orgánica. Este equilibrio ayuda a los agricultores a ganarse la vida cuidando la tierra.

**Próximo paso** – El Consejo de la Unión Europea debe aprobar formalmente las nuevas reglas. Una vez aprobadas y publicadas en el Diario Oficial de la UE, entrarán en vigor al día siguiente.

**Mensaje en una frase** – La UE ha aprobado reglas agrícolas más claras y simples que aumentan el apoyo a los agricultores y protegen el medio ambiente al mismo tiempo.

International shipping accounts for 3 percent of greenhouse gas emissions. But a new path is emerging: starting in 2026, sailing cargo ships will set off from France to the United States, some flying the French flag. The big question is whether this innovation can succeed in convincing industry giants. Our France 2 colleagues report.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a tangible innovation—sailing cargo ships—that aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping, a major polluting industry. This initiative starting in 2026 has broad environmental significance and potential large-scale impact on climate action, with sufficient context about the upcoming implementation and its goals.
articles.personality_title: Sailing cargo ships set to reduce pollution in global shipping by 2026
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – International shipping is responsible for about 3 percent of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions. These emissions contribute to climate change, making the shipping industry one of the more polluting sectors globally.

**What happened** – Starting in 2026, new sailing cargo ships will begin trips from France to the United States. These ships will use wind power instead of relying solely on engines that burn fossil fuels. Some of these ships will sail under the French flag, marking a significant step for France in cleaner shipping.

**Impact** – Using wind to move cargo ships is a new idea for such large-scale shipping. This approach could greatly lower the pollution caused by moving goods across oceans. If successful, it could encourage big shipping companies to adopt cleaner technologies, reducing emissions from a sector that has been hard to clean up.

**What's next step** – The main challenge is whether shipping companies will support and invest in sailing cargo ships. The trips starting in 2026 will provide important information about how well these ships work and if they can be a practical alternative for the industry.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Starting in 2026, sailing cargo ships from France to the U.S. will test a cleaner way to carry goods across oceans, aiming to cut pollution from shipping.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des cargos à voile pour réduire la pollution du transport maritime dès 2026
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le transport maritime international représente environ 3 % des émissions mondiales de gaz à effet de serre. Ces émissions contribuent au changement climatique, ce qui fait du secteur maritime l’un des plus polluants.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – À partir de 2026, de nouveaux cargos à voile partiront de France vers les États-Unis. Ces navires utiliseront la force du vent au lieu de moteurs fonctionnant aux combustibles fossiles. Certains de ces cargos navigueront sous pavillon français, marquant une avancée importante pour la France dans le transport maritime plus propre.

**Impact** – Utiliser le vent pour faire avancer des cargos de cette taille est une idée nouvelle à grande échelle. Cette méthode pourrait fortement réduire la pollution liée au transport de marchandises par mer. Si cela fonctionne, cela pourrait encourager les grandes compagnies maritimes à adopter des technologies plus écologiques.

**Prochaine étape** – Le principal défi est de savoir si les entreprises maritimes soutiendront et investiront dans ces cargos à voile. Les voyages débutant en 2026 permettront de tester leur efficacité et leur viabilité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Dès 2026, des cargos à voile relieront la France aux États-Unis pour tester un moyen plus propre de transporter des marchandises et réduire la pollution maritime.
articles.personality_title_es: Cargueros a vela para reducir la contaminación del transporte marítimo a partir de 2026
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El transporte marítimo internacional representa alrededor del 3 % de las emisiones globales de gases de efecto invernadero. Estas emisiones contribuyen al cambio climático, haciendo que esta industria sea una de las más contaminantes.

**Qué pasó** – A partir de 2026, nuevos cargueros a vela partirán de Francia hacia Estados Unidos. Estos barcos usarán la fuerza del viento en lugar de motores que queman combustibles fósiles. Algunos navegarán bajo bandera francesa, representando un avance importante para Francia en transporte marítimo más limpio.

**Impacto** – Usar el viento para mover cargueros de gran tamaño es una idea nueva a gran escala. Esta forma podría reducir mucho la contaminación causada por el transporte de mercancías por mar. Si tiene éxito, podría motivar a las grandes empresas navieras a adoptar tecnologías más limpias.

**Próximo paso** – El reto principal es si las empresas de transporte apoyarán e invertirán en cargueros a vela. Los viajes que comienzan en 2026 serán clave para probar su funcionamiento y si son una alternativa práctica.

**Resumen en una frase** – Desde 2026, cargueros a vela entre Francia y EE. UU. probarán una forma más limpia de transportar mercancías y reducir la contaminación marítima.
